content.question:
<math alttext="R K B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>RKB</mi></math> and <math alttext="J C M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>JCM</mi></math> are two competing firms that are considering which project to develop. <math alttext="R K B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>RKB</mi></math> will develop either Project Alpha or Project Beta. <math alttext="J C M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>JCM</mi></math> will develop either Project <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> or Project <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>. The payoff matrix provided shows the payoffs for each combination of strategies, and both players (<math alttext="R K B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>RKB</mi></math> and <math alttext="J C M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>JCM</mi></math>) have complete information. The first value in each cell represents the payoff for <math alttext="R K B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>RKB</mi></math>, and the second value represents the payoff for <math alttext="J C M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>JCM</mi></math>. Each firm independently and simultaneously chooses its strategy.
Which of the following conclusions is supported by the information in the payoff matrix?

choices.label: There is no combination of project choices that results in a Nash equilibrium.
There are multiple combinations of project choices that result in Nash equilibria.
<math alttext="R K B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>RKB</mi></math> has a dominant strategy, but <math alttext="J C M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>JCM</mi></math> does not.
<math alttext="J C M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>JCM</mi></math> has a dominant strategy, but <math alttext="R K B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>RKB</mi></math> does not.
Neither firm has a dominant strategy.

content.answer: <math alttext="R K B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>RKB</mi></math> has a dominant strategy, but <math alttext="J C M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>JCM</mi></math> does not.
